<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_allocate:
```c
void *
MHD_pool_allocate (struct MemoryPool *pool,
                   size_t size,
                   bool from_end)
{
  void *ret;
  size_t asize;

  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
  asize = ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE (size);
  if ( (0 == asize) && (0 != size) )
    return NULL; /* size too close to SIZE_MAX */
  if (asize > pool->end - pool->pos)
    return NULL;
  if (from_end)
  {
    ret = &pool->memory[pool->end - asize];
    pool->end -= asize;
  }
  else
  {
    ret = &pool->memory[pool->pos];
    pool->pos += asize;
  }
  _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (ret, size);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
pool->end -= asize;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The statement pool->end -= asize; itself does not call any <string.h> routine and therefore does not by itself violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. The function performs checks (asize computed, asize > pool->end - pool->pos guarded) that prevent reducing pool->end past pool->pos. A violation of Rule 21.17 could occur later if the returned pointer (ret) is passed to a string.h function with a length larger than the allocated region. Example concrete violation: if asize == 0 (size == 0) and pool->end == pool->size, ret becomes &pool->memory[pool->end] (one-past-end). If client code then incorrectly calls memcpy(ret, src, 1) or strcpy(ret, src) the string.h function would access beyond the bounds — that would violate Rule 21.17.
